channel.title: The Hon. Marco Rubio
channel.description: The Hon. Marco Rubio U.S. Senator, Florida (Remarks as Prepared for Delivery)

item.title: In 1980, I watched my first Republican convention with my grandfather.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: He was born to a farming family in rural Cuba. Childhood polio left him permanently disabled. Because he couldn't work the farm, his family sent him to school, and he became the only one in the family who could read.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: As a boy, I would sit on our porch and listen to his stories about history, politics and baseball while he puffed on one of his three daily Padron cigars.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: I don't recall everything we talked about, but the one thing I remember, is the one thing he wanted me to never forget. The dreams he had when he was young became impossible to achieve.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: But there was no limit to how far I could go, because I was an American.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: For those of us who were born and raised in this country, it's easy to forget how special America is. But my grandfather understood how different America is from the rest of the world, because he knew what life was like outside America.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Tonight, you'll hear from another man who understands what makes America exceptional.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Mitt Romney knows America's prosperity didn't happen because our government simply spent more. It happened because our people used their own money to open a business. And when they succeed, they hire more people, who then invest or spend their money in the economy, helping others start a business and create jobs.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Mitt Romney's success in business is well known. But he's more than that.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: He's a devoted husband, father and grandfather. A generous member of his community and church. Everywhere he's been, he's volunteered his time and talent to make things better for those around him.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: We are blessed that soon, he will be the president of the United States.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Our problem with President Obama isn't that he's a bad person. By all accounts, he too is a good husband, and a good father -- and thanks to lots of practice, a pretty good golfer.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Our problem is he's a bad president.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: The new slogan for the president's campaign is "Forward."
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: A government that spends $1 trillion more than it takes in.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: An $800 billion stimulus that created more debt than jobs.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: A government intervention into health care paid for with higher taxes and cuts to Medicare.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Scores of new rules and regulations.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: These ideas don't move us "Forward," they take us "Backwards."
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: These are tired and old big government ideas. Ideas that people come to America to get away from. Ideas that threaten to make America more like the rest of the world, instead of helping the world become more like America.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Under Barack Obama, the only "Change" is that "Hope" has been hard to find.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Now millions of Americans are insecure about their future. But instead of inspiring us by reminding us of what makes us special, he divides us against each other.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: He tells Americans they're worse off because others are better off. That people got rich by making others poor.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Hope and Change has become Divide and Conquer.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: No matter how you feel about President Obama, this election is about your future, not his. And it's not simply a choice between a Democrat and a Republican.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: It's a choice about what kind of country we want America to be.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: As we prepare to make this choice, we should remember what made us special. For most of history almost everyone was poor. Power and wealth belonged to only a few.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Your rights were whatever your rulers allowed you to have. Your future was determined by your past. If your parents were poor, so would you be. If you were born without opportunities, so were your children.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: But America was founded on the principle that every person has God-given rights. That power belongs to the people. That government exists to protect our rights and serve our interests. That we shouldn't be trapped in the circumstances of our birth. That we should be free to go as far as our talents and work can take us.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: We are special because we've been united not by a common race or ethnicity. We're bound together by common values. That family is the most important institution in society. That almighty God is the source of all we have.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Special, because we've never made the mistake of believing that we are so smart that we can rely solely on our leaders or our government.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Our national motto is "In God we Trust," reminding us that faith in our Creator is the most important American value of all.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: And special because we've always understood the scriptural admonition that "for everyone to whom much is given, from him much will be required."
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: We are a blessed people. And we have honored those blessings with the enduring example of an exceptional America.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: I know that for so many of you, these last few years have tested your faith in the promise of America.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Maybe you are at an age when you thought you would be entering retirement. But now, because your savings and investments are wiped out, your future is uncertain.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Maybe, after years of hard work, this was the time you expected to be your prime earning years. But instead, you've been laid off, and your house is worth less than your mortgage.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Maybe you did everything you were told you needed to do to get ahead. You studied hard and finished school. But now, you owe thousands of dollars in student loans. You can't find a job in your field. And you've moved back in with your parents.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: You want to believe we're still that place where anything is possible. But things just don't seem to be getting better. And you are starting to wonder if things will ever be the same again.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Yes, we live in a troubled time. But the story of those who came before us reminds us that America has always been about new beginnings.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: And Mitt Romney is running for president because he knows that if we are willing to do for our children what our parents did for us, life in America can be better than it has ever been. My mother was one of seven girls whose parents went to bed hungry so their children wouldn't. My father lost his mother when he was nine. He left school and went to work for the next 70 years.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: They emigrated to America with little more than the hope of a better life.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: My dad was a bartender. My mom was a cashier, a maid and a stock clerk at K-Mart. They never made it big. They were never rich. And yet they were successful. Because just a few decades removed from hopelessness, they made possible for us all the things that had been impossible for them.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Many nights I heard my father's keys jingling at the door as he came home after another 16-hour day. Many mornings, I woke up just as my mother got home from the overnight shift at K-Mart
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: When you're young, the meaning of moments like these escapes you. But now, as my own children get older, I understand it better.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: My Dad used to tell us: "En este pais, ustedes van a poder lograr todas las cosas que nosotros no pudimos" "In this country, you will be able to accomplish all the things we never could."
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: A few years ago during a speech, I noticed a bartender behind a portable bar at the back of the ballroom. I remembered my father who had worked for many years as a banquet bartender.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: He was grateful for the work he had, but that's not the life he wanted for us.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: He stood behind a bar in the back of the room all those years, so one day I could stand behind a podium in the front of a room.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: That journey, from behind that bar to behind this podium, goes to the essence of the American miracle -- that we're exceptional not because we have more rich people here.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: We're special because dreams that are impossible anywhere else, come true here.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: That's not just my story. That's your story. That's our story.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: It's the story of your mother who struggled to give you what she never had.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: It's the story of your father who worked two jobs so doors closed for him would open for you.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: The story of that teacher or that coach who taught you the lessons that shaped who you are today.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: And it's the story of a man who was born into an uncertain future in a foreign country. His family came to America to escape revolution. They struggled through poverty and the great depression. And yet he rose to be an admired businessman, and public servant.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: And in November, his son, Mitt Romney, will be elected President of the United States.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: We are all just a generation or two removed from someone who made our future the purpose of their lives.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: America is the story of everyday people who did extraordinary things. A story woven deep into the fabric of our society.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Their stories may never be famous, but in the lives they lived, you find the living essence of America's greatness. To make sure America is still a place where tomorrow is always better than yesterday, that is what our politics should be about.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: And that is what we are deciding in this election.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Do we want our children to inherit our hopes and dreams, or do we want them to inherit our problems?
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Mitt Romney believes that if we succeed in changing the direction of our country, our children and grandchildren will be the most prosperous generation ever, and their achievements will astonish the world.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: The story of our time will be written by Americans who haven't yet been born.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: Let's make sure they write that we did our part. That in the early years of this new century, we lived in an uncertain time. But we did not allow fear to cause us to abandon what made us special.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: We chose more freedom instead of more government.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: We chose the principles of our founding to solve the challenges of our time.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: We chose a special man to lead us in a special time.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: We chose Mitt Romney to lead our nation.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio

item.title: And because we did, the American Miracle lived on for another generation to inherit.
item.author: The Hon. Marco Rubio
